titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
On rising this morning I found it bitter cold— The moon nearly full was descending about W.N.W. to the horizon— Venus was less than 5 minutes risen, and Arcturus rose within 5 minutes after— Mercury rose about 6. and the Sun at 6:56.— I put my thermometer out in the Seminary, and a quarter of an hour before Sunrise it was at 20 of Fahrenheit, 4 degrees colder than I have ever known it in this climate so early as this in the Season. The ground was covered with Snow, which disappeared in the course of the day— I read in Anderson §. 31. Dioptric Micrometers, by Ramsden and G. Dollond— And §. 32
§. 32. Dioptric Micrometer, constructed by T. Jones— It is very tedious work to read 200 large quarto pages with references to 20 plates, and alphabets of Algebra, about the construction of Micrometers; but it is the glory of human ingenuity to contemplate the profusion of mind which has been bestowed in contrivances to facilitate the use of the Telescope— Charles sent his three Sons, with their Nurses, Mrs Field and Maria, and his waiting man John, this morning into Boston, and came with his wife and daughter Louisa Catherine to stay with me till next Monday, when they are to go in to Boston for the Winter— E. Price Greenleaf was here, and borrowed a German Dictionary and Grammar; and 4 Volumes of Wieland’s works, and Klopstock’s Messiah to learn German, as in the two preceding Winters he has learnt Spanish and Italian.— This Evening with Charles and his wife I went and paid visits to our neighbours Mr William Appleton, Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Mr Beale— We found Mr Price Greenleaf at Mr Beale’s— Weather yet unsettled and chilly.

Another fall of Snow in the Night—and then rain— Then cleared up— When I rose I found Venus and Arcturus upwards of an hour risen— A hazy cloud at the Southeastern horizon intercepted the sight of Mercury at his rise, and before he emerged from it the twilight had rendered him invisible— The Sun was five minutes risen before I saw him— My thermometer in the open air was at 36— I read in Pearson § 33. The divide Eye lens Micrometer § 34 Ramsdens’s Catoptric Micrometer; and § 35 Dr Maskelyne’s Prismatic Micrometer— And this reading led me to consult several Articles in Rees’s Encyclopaedia, particularly the Theodolite, and the morning melted away and was gone.— I receive almost every day several Letters which I find no time to answer— Visit this afternoon from Mr Lunt, who came to consult me concerning a disposition of the Choir of Singers of the parish, to lay aside the Psalm and Hymn book, used at the Sunday worship, and to substitute another in its place. I enquired what collection they proposed to take— That was not yet determined.— What was the motive for the change— The hymns now in use were not well adapted to the modern music— The whole concern resolves itself into a thirst for change, and novelty.— Mr Lunt said that Dr Frothingham’s Society in Boston, and this Church at Quincy, were the only Religious Societies which still adhere to the collection made by Dr. Belknap—first introduced inand revised by Dr. Channing inIt is an excellent collection, and will not be supplanted by a better one— There are several more recent compilations used in the congregational churches at Boston; and one made by Mr Greenwood for the Stone Chapel Church at Boston, with Episcopalian forms and an unitarian creed. I told Mr Lunt, that whatever the Society here might chuse to do in the case should have my ready acquiescence— That I was not personally given to change, and thought little if any improvement was to be expected from discarding Dr. Belknap, and taking up another— That I did not well see how the music could be affected by it as there are not more than five or six measures in the whole book, and the same
same tune which serves for one psalm or hymn is equally adaptable to 50— Mr Lunt did not say, but I had a surmise that he wished to make a collection himself, to be used by the parish here— He inquired if I had not made a version of the Psalms— I said I had, and if I could find the manuscript would shew it to him.— He borrowed the collection given me by Lowell Mason, and containing my hymn—[“]Hark! ‘tis the holy Temple’s bell.”— Charles and his wife spent the Evening at Mr Lunt’s.

As yesterday I found Venus and Arcturus nearly an hour risen but a thick haze at the Southeastern horizon, and then the brightening dawn intercepted the sight of Mercury, and also the first appearance of the Sun.— Fahrenheit before Sun rise at 28. Read Pearson § 36. The Cuneiform Micrometer— This is an invention of his own— § 37. Rochon’s Crystal Micrometer— From which I turned to the Articles Micrometer and Telescope in Rees’s Cyclopaedia— The result of all this reading is lamentation for the want of Time, and impossibility of prosecuting the study to any profit— Received several Letters to be answered; and under cover from Governor Edward Everett, the Taunton Whig Newspaper, containing his Speech at the late Convention of the Friends of Education in the County of Norfolk; at Dedham— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— His wife received a letter from Mrs. W. S. Smith at New-York—dated the 1st.— They arrived there Tuesday Morning; and my wife and family, proceeded the same day for Philadelphia— Deacon Spear came, and I went with him in his Carryall, to my Pine hill woodlot stopping on the way at the bank, where Mr Lemuel Brackett took my Oath to the certificate that Dr Amos Windship was a Surgeon in the Frigate Alliance in 1779.— I met also Shadrach Thayer, With a County and Town Tax Bill assessed upon me at Braintree— I viewed the woodlot upon Pine Hill; but the ground was so wet, by the recent rains that I was very soon obliged to return: leaving to Charles to determine how much of it shall be stripped of wood the coming winter.— After dinner Charles and his wife rode to Weymouth.— I had a quantity of Acorns, Shagbark walnuts and Honey locust seeds, sown by Kirk in the cross border at the North end of the Orchard behind the House—and gathered the last winter pears— Peter Turner this Evening brought me a pair of shoes, and said I was the only man for whom he made shoes— He is laying out a road from the Stone Meeting House to Mount Wollaston, and asked a contribution from me, for its supposed benefit to my farm there; but I declined— He said the saving of the distance by the old road would be 76 rods— Dr Duggan brought the Petition of Lydia Faxon, for a Pension, which I am to present at the approaching Session of Congress— I visited my garden this afternoon; but the ground was so damp, that I risked taking a Cold— The leaves have almost all fallen from the trees, and the whole aspect of things is cheerless and desolate— I fear I shall be disappointed of all my plantations this Season, by the rains and premature Snows.

Beclouded morning. No observation Fahrenheit 46. About Noon, began the rain and continued the whole day and evening. Mr Lunt preached this Morning from the Wisdom of Solomon—1.6.—“For Wisdom, is a loving Spirit.”— The first instance that I ever knew of a text taken by a Protestant preacher, from the Apocrypha— The Sermon I thought excellent— He distinguished three kinds of Wisdom—that from above—the leading principle of which is benevolence— Worldly wisdom, the ruling characteristic of which is selfishness; and wisdom from the pit, under the guidance of malice— Of these, the only true Wisdom is that from Heaven; selfishness, being more properly the parent of Artifice and cunning; and the infernal wisdom operating by fraud and deceit— The afternoon discourse was from Titus 2.11. For the grace of God, that bringeth Salvation, hath appeared to all men 12 teaching us, that, denying ungodliness, and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world— Charles and I rode to and from meeting after dinner in heavy rain— I read the second Sermon of the 12th Volume of Saurin, upon the glory of the Christian; the glory of the cross—preached on the Sunday before Ascension day— There are some historical notices of the divisions in the Christian Church, immediately succeeding the death of Jesus, on the question of whether the rite of circumcision, and the other ordinances of the Levitical Law should be continued, or were to be considered as abolished— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, notwithstanding the rain, and took tea, and spent the Evening with us.— I had read this morning Pearson § 38— On the different methods of determining the constant angle of a doubly refracting prism of rock crystal, or of a glass wedge—and §. 39. The ocular crystal micrometer— I turned also to §. 103. which is an alphabetical List of 123. Observatories with columns marking their places— Latitudes Longitudes in Time— Longitudes in Arc. Astronomers attached to them, and Stations— But fifty of them are without name of any Astronomer, and of course without constant observers.— There are however 73. with names of Astronomers; though I suppose a large proportion of them are rather nominal than real Observatories. There is one set down for Philadelphia.

Rain all night and all this day— Read in Pearson §. 40. The spherical Crystal micrometer, by G. Dollond § 41. Dr Brewster’s Patent Micrometrical Telescope— This Section refers to his Treatise on new philosophical instruments— His Patent instrument is said to be made by the Tulleys and sold by Harris, Mathematical Instrument maker of Holborn—London— Of the list of Observatories there are 15 in England, 14 in France, and several in almost every Country of Europe— There are others in Africa, Asia, and several in South-America; though very few effective establishments any where.— Mr John Whicher was here, and complained that Coll. Sylvanus Thayer, who is charged by the War Department with the superintendence of the works on George’s, and Castle Island in Boston Harbour has made contracts with him, and with many others for stone, from the
the granite quarries in this town, and now, when the stone has been furnished and delivered, refuses to pay for it— He enquired how they could obtain justice in this case— Said they had consulted Mr Gourgas, the lawyer in this town, who told them he did not know what was to be done, and advised them to come to me. I told him there were three ways of proceeding, either or all of which might be expedient and remedial— A Memorial to the Secretary of War stating the facts, and calling on him to order Coll. Thayer to fulfil his contract. Or, a Memorial to the President of the United States, to the same effect—or they might commence a suit at law, in the Court of Common Pleas, for the County of Suffolk at Boston—which I supposed could be done by Mr Gourgas— I enquired what reason Coll Thayer had given for refusing payment— He said, it was that Congress had not made a sufficient appropriation— That he had money only sufficient to pay the workmen—and if he should pay the contractors for Stone the work must be stop’d— Mr Whicher thanked me for my advice, and said he would consult his fellow sufferers— Mr Harvey Field was here, and settled with Charles for his rent. He is one of the liberal seceders from the whig party, much opposed to the 15 gallon licence Law— I received a Letter from my wife, at Washington, where she arrived with the family last Wednesday evening; safe and well. [symbols]

The rain continued through part of the Night, but when I rose the Clouds were sweeping rapidly away— I had glimpses of Venus and Arcturus risen some time— Mercury rose say from 7 to 10 minutes past 6. and was visible just half an hour— The Sun rose precisely at 7. I read Pearson §. 42. The Lamp Micrometer, by Sir William Herschel— §. 43— Binocular Spider’s line and glass-disc Micrometers. § 44. On the use of position Micrometers— I look into other books upon Astronomy plane and physical, and am appalled at the field that opens before me— Mr Peter Whitney the minister came upon a visit to take leave— Then Mr Lunt and Mr Brigham as a deputation from the School-Committee came to converse with me, on the suggestions I had made to Mr Lunt concerning the establishment of a high School in this Town— It was that if the Town would assume the expence of establishing a high School, the fund might be united with that of my fathers bequest, and the Academy contemplated by him might be immediately carried into effect.— In the course of the conversation, it was apparent, that the Committee apprehend a difficulty in prevailing upon the Town to undertake the expence of a high School, though he said that with a population of 3000 the Law expressly provided that they should— They said that Captain John Whitney, the chairman of the School Committee was to have come with them but was unwell— Mr Brigham intimated a desire that the proposition for the Union of my fathers projected Academy, and this high school should come from the Trustees of his fund; but I did not concur in this opinion— I said I had gone upon the assumption that
that the Town was required by Law to keep a high school. On that supposition I supposed it must be brought by the School Committee before the Town for consideration, and I supposed the town would instruct the Committee to prepare estimates of the expense, and a plan for the establishment of the School. Then would be the time for conferring with the Trustees of my father’s fund— A man by the name of John H. Adams came with a model for a patent cooking fire stove and made sundry enquiries concerning the Patent Laws, which I answered as well as I was able; and for the rest gave him a copy of the printed pamphlet of information from the Commissioner of Patents to the applicants for Patent rights— Mr Edward Cruft and his Son William just returned from an excursion to Europe, paid us a morning visit— Mr Cruft has been to St. Petersburg, Moscow and Stockholm, and has much to say concerning those cities— Lemuel Spear came this afternoon with a notice that the fence viewers would go, Thursday to survey the fence between my lot and that of Benjamin V. French at the Mount Wollaston farm.— I asked him to send me the notice in writing, and a copy of the written application from French and others, which he said he would do to-morrow— Josiah Adams junr. and Mr Gay were here this Evening to speak of the Patent for the bark cutter for which Adams has had a caveat entered— They are not yet ready to take out the Patent, but Adams will write to me, when they are— I had a row of white oak acorns sown by Kirk in the row across the north end of the Orchard—and went to the porch of Charles’s house and saw the sunset precisely at 5— Cursory perusal of a Volume of La Fayette’s correspondence.

Clear morning— I found Venus just risen— Arcturus rose just a quarter of an hour later; but to my great disappointment although the horizon E. by S. where he rises was apparently clear I saw not Mercury at all, though I had seen him rise yesterday, and for half an hour after he had risen— I am utterly unable to account for my failing to see him— I read Pearson §. 45. Experimental comparison of several Micrometers; with tables—and here ends the long succession of Sections upon Micrometers— Mere appendages to the eye-glass of a Telescope; for the measurement of small angles; but indispensable for observations of the Stars, from which any useful inference is to be drawn— §. 46 On clamps and tangent screws. These one would suppose, are within the special province of the instrument-maker— The part of the mechanic— But they are treated of here with as much earnestness, as the Telescope itself— §. 47. Of the Vernier.— This instrument was invented by a Frenchman in 1631 within one year after the death of Kepler— Vernier was the inventor of a nautical quadrant; to which this little scale was an index— He has no credit
credit for his quadrant; but the Vernier has immortalized his name— Henry Hardwick was here, and proposed certain ditching upon the salt-marsh land, adjoining between him and me, at the Mount Wollaston farm; but the Season is so far advanced, and my departure for Washington so near at hand, that I am obliged to postpone the further consideration of this question, till next Summer— Mrs Lawrence the widow, brought her deceased husband’s land-warrant, and the copy of a Letter from Jason Harrison of Jefferson City, Missouri, to Dr Shurtleff, stating that the present occupant of the land, which has been sold for taxes, would compound for the right of Lawrence’s son, the sale having been made while he was a minor— Mrs Lawrence feels much solicitude also concerning her petition for a pension, and complains much of being destitute, and having lost what little property she had by the failure of a bank— John Tilden, Post-master at East Marshfield, called here with his son, to offer his services for the safe delivery of any thing I might have to send to his Post-Office— His Son is about emigrating to the State of Illinois; where he says that the Revd. Elbridge G. Howe is already gone— Charles came out and dined with us; and returned to Boston, after dinner— In the Evening I called at Mr Lunt’s, with the School returns to the Legislature, for the last two years which he had lent me— He was not at home, and I left them with Mrs Lunt— I met him afterwards at the Lyceum, where Mr Cornell the Minister of the orthodox church delivered a Lecture upon the delusions of the Imagination, about three quarters of an hour— Entertaining, and Instructive— Modest and liberal— After returning home, I travelled through half a volume of La Fayette’s writings, by cutting open the leaves.

Cloudy, starless morning— I read Pearson §48 on the reading Microscope— 49. On the plumbline. 50. On the Spirit-level and 51. On Artificial Horizons— These are all inventions for improving and perfecting the great instrument of astronomical observation, the Telescope.— The practical usefulness of this Science seems confined to Navigators, on the Ocean; and they generally know little more of it than to take the Altitude, of the Sun upon the Meridian, and with the help of tables in the Nautical Almanac, to work out their Longitude.— To me, the observation of the Sun, Moon and Stars has been for a great portion of my life a pleasure of gratified curiosity; of ever returning wonder, and of reverence for the creator and mover of these unnumbered worlds— There is something of awful enjoyment, in observing the rising and setting of the Sun— That flashing beam of his first appearance upon the horizon. That sinking of the last ray beneath it—that perpetual revolution of the great and little bear round the Pole—that rising of the whole Constellation of Orion from the horizontal to the perpendicular position—and his ride through the Heavens with his belt, his nebulous sword, and his four corner stars of the first magnitude, are sources of delight to me which never tire. Even
Even the optical delusion, by which the motion of the Earth from West to East, appears to the eye as the movement of the whole firmament from East to West, swells the conception of magnificence to the incomprehensible infinite— There is indeed intermingled with all this a painful sensation of desire to know more of this stupendous system, of sorrow—in reflecting how little we ever can know of it, and of almost desponding hope that we may know more of it hereafter— While we were at breakfast there came on a heavy shower and gale, which continued in Squalls in quick succession through the whole day— At 2. O’Clock I rode with Kirke to the Mount Wollaston Farm, where the Fence-viewers, Lemuel Spear,Silvester, andmet to survey the ground where B. V. French and other proprietors of the Salt-marsh adjoining upon my upland had summoned me to make a partition fence— Neither French himself the instigator of the whole proceeding, nor Lewis Bass one of the signers of the complaint came there at all.HollisBrackett and Pearson Wild came, but neither of them had his Deed; nor could either of them point out where the partition fence should run— There never has been a fence there— They said their Deeds bounded them by the upland; but the line between the upland and the meadow is altogether undefined, and they could not point it out— Hollis attempted to encroach by trickery, and pretended I had agreed to leave it to the Fence viewers. I told him I should leave it to them; not as a reference; but to decide according to Law— Bracket, stuck down a stake about 12 feet on the upland which I only said I thought an encroachment— The fence viewers refused to do any thing without the Deeds, and I came home in a hard squall of wind, with a torrent of rain— Alpheus Spear paid me a balance for the parish tax on the Mount Wollaston farm for the years 1836–7–8— Dined between 4 and 5 O’Clock— John A. Green brought me a proof slip of my answer to the Committee of the Whig Convention at Halifax which nominated me for re-election to Congress— They published my answer in the Old Colony Memorial at Plymouth, whence it has been republished in a Hingham Patriot extra. Green is also to republish it in the next Quincy Patriot.— The slip had only a part of the answer.— Green told me that the Administration democrats of this District, were to vote for William Morton Jackson of Plymouth, a warm abolitionist, against me.— They had made no nomination, but would act in secret concert together.— Their choice of an abolitionist to support the Van Buren Administration is a specimen of electioneering honesty— I opened the leaves of another Volume of La Fayette.

The rain had scarcely ceased when I rose having been awaked by the striking of the Clock which I thought was 5, but was only 3— My thermometer was at 67. but the moisture of the atmosphere was streaming down the glass windows of the chamber; I made a small fire and sat down to write for about three hours— Then read Pearson, § 52. On Flamsteeds and La Caille’s
La Caille’s methods of observing. and §. 53 on the Transit Clock— There is in the first of these some notice of the first establishment of the Royal Observatory at Greenwich, in August 1676, founded by Sir Jonas Moor, and of which Flamsteed was the first Astronomer— The Historical account of Flamsteed’s labours, is interesting, and leads to enquiries which I would gladly pursue— His Historia Celestis and his Catalogue of British Stars, are necessary Articles for a good observatory— His first amanuensis was J. Stafford, and after his death, in May 1688, Abraham Sharp, a skilful mechanic was his assistant— Flamsteed died in 1719, and was succeeded by Dr Halley, then 62 years of age; but who lived till 1742— Here the notices stop; but Halley was succeeded by Bradley, the discoverer of the aberration of light and of the nutation of the pole of the Earth— He died the 12th. of July 1761. at the age of 70—and was succeeded by Dr Maskelyne—but for the sequel of this History I would enquire further— La Cailles observations were made shortly before the middle of the last century, at the Cape of Good Hope— The registers of both these Astronomers were kept in the Latin language— The transit-Clock, is the preliminary to the description of the transit instrument— I had a visit to take leave from Augustus Whitney, who is preaching at Dedham in the place of Dr Lamson who is sick— Charles came out and dined with us, and immediately after returned to Boston— I filled one of my seedling pots and planted in it sundry red wedge Apple-seeds; but the alternate succession of flooding rains and sharp frosts for the last month has almost totally disappointed my plantations for the present year.— I wrote three short and indispensable Letters— Charles brought out an Atlas Newspaper extra with intelligence of the result of the elections in the City of New-York on the first three days of this week— The whigs to their extasy of joy have succeeded, and Cambreleng and Ely Moore have received their dismission— The returns from the State are yet to be received— In the evening I opened the leaves of another Volume of Lafayette’s writings, and found an affecting Letter to Latour Maubourg, on the death of Madame Lafayette in December 1807— When they were married he was but 16 and she but 14 years old— They lived in the most perfect harmony thirty-three years, a model of conjugal affection— She had a deep and strong religious feeling and consequently a holy and abiding impulse to the performance of her duties— As samples of their age and Nation, how glorious they were! Mr Green brought me a proof-slip of the remainder of my Letter to the Committee of the Whig Halifax-Convention, which I revised.— The weather cleared off, cold.

The windows were all frosted withinside by congealed vapour— Thermometer at 22. Venus and Arcturus an hour and more risen before me; Mercury not to be seen— I read Pearson § 54. On the properties of the Transit Instrument, and here shall be obliged to suspend the further perusal of this valuable work
work— While packing up for my departure, I had a morning visit from Dr Channing, Dr Tuckerman, Mr Phillips, Son of the late Lieutt Governor Phillips, and Dr Channing’s Son— They were here nearly two hours, and I had a long conversation with them upon Slavery and Anti-Slavery; abolition Societies and Slave-holding policy.— Doctor Channing asked my opinions, upon two points— One the present test question of the abolitionists—the immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia and the territory of Florida; and the other whether in the event of the adoption of those measures the Southern States would secede from the Union— I said first, that to make a test question upon the immediate abolition was absurd and had something captious in it, because it was notoriously impracticable— There is in the present House of Representatives of nearly two to one opposed to the consideration or discussion of the subject; and if the proposition should be made they would refuse to consider it— Mr. Phillips said he wished I would take some method of publishing this opinion— I told him of the Letter I wrote to Mr C. P. Kirkland, and said I should probably take some occasion to express similar opinions at the approaching Session of Congress— But that my opinions will have no influence upon the abolitionists; who have already given me repeated warnings that they will desert and oppose me, if I do not come over to them, in the creed of immediate abolition— I said, it was necessary to consider the Spirit of abolitionism, as a fact as well as a theory— As a phenomenon to be studied; and over which no individual can have much controul— As to the second question, I did not believe that the South would dissolve the Union, if Slavery should be abolished in the District of Columbia and in Florida— South Carolina might perhaps secede, but she could not carry the South with her— Dr Channing appeared to entertain great apprehensions for the Union and deep concern at the violence of the abolition Spirit— We had also some conversation upon the currency, Bank and Subtreasury questions.— Mr Phillips expressed himself strongly averse to a National Bank— I said I thought a National Bank, indispensable for the safe collection and disbursement of the revenue, and if I had the power, that is if I could prevail upon Congress and the People to be of the same opinion, I would establish one to-morrow. But now there is a prejudice against it in the opinions of a large portion of the People throughout the Union— It is a bone of party contention, and therefore not now expedient— Nor should I have the same confidence in a National bank, to furnish a sound currency to regulate exchanges, and to check the over-issues of all the State Banks as did the two former Banks of the United States each for twenty years.— The main difficulty would now be to make up a Capital, for a National Bank; four fifths of the Capital of the last Bank having consisted of public securities, bearing an interest of 6. per cent, to which the faith of the Nation was pledged, and which now no longer exist— I promised to call
call and see Dr Channing in Boston, before my departure, for Washington— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, and immediately after dinner, I came with Louisa C. Smith into Boston— She stop’d at Mr James H. Foster’s in Bedford Street, and I alighted at my Son’s House, N. 3. Hancock Avenue— The road was hard frozen, and rough, and the weather cold as mid-winter— Sent Kirk who had brought us in, immediately back to Quincy with the Carriage and Horses— I was stiffened with cold— Charles immediately told me that Mr Fletcher and two other Gentlemen had been here to invite me to attend the whig Caucus at Faneuil Hall, at 7. O’Clock this Evening, and to address the Meeting— I thought there would be an impropriety in this— The Gentlemen had said they would call again at 6. O’Clock; and to avoid a discussion with them, and the baldness of a flat refusal, I went and took tea, and spent the early part of the evening with my old friend Joseph Hall, now in the 78th year of his age— His two sons, and his Sister Elizabeth who lives with him were there— He takes no further interest in public affairs; but loves to remember the political struggles in which he took part in days of yore.— On returning to Charles’s house between 8 and 9 I found that Mr P. C. Brooks had called to see me, and that Mr Fletcher, and two companions had returned at 6. O’Clock to repeat the invitation of my attendance this Evening at the whig Caucus, in Faneuil Hall—upon being informed that I had gone out they enquired where I could be found— Charles said he did not know; but that to be candid he believed I had some objection to attending the Caucus: upon which they desisted— The impropriety of my appearance at the Caucus would have been aggravated by the fact that the whig party itself is convulsed with a foolish feud about a license law prohibiting the sale of spirituous liquors in quantities less than 15 gallons at a time—

I rose about an hour earlier than I had intended—and took the orientation of Charles’s House, by observing the rise of Venus Arcturus and the Sun over the chimney-tops— Mercury was not visible— I betook myself to Charles’s study, and wrote till breakfast time; merely reading over again Pearson’s § 54. On the properties of the transit instrument—invented by Roemer, and of which the special purpose is to observe and ascertain the right ascension of the stars by their daily passage of the Meridian— Dr Halley first introduced its use, about 1750 at the Greenwich observatory, since which it has been used generally superseding the former method of ascertain the transit, by measuring correspondent altitudes— I attended meeting this morning and afternoon at the first Congregational Church, to the Society of which I formerly belonged— Dr. Nathaniel L Frothingham is now their Pastor, but is confined to his house with a severe cold. The morning preacher was my old friend and classmate Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris and his text was Isaiah 33.9. “The earth mourneth and languisheth; Lebanon is ashamed and hewn down; Sharon is like a wilderness: and Bashan and Carmel shake off their fruits[”]— The discourse considered this as descriptive of the fall of the leaf and of the year: and then illustrated this change of the Season, by analogical
analogical similitudes to the decline and extinction of human life— I connected involuntarily the day when I first knew him, in March 1786. and the day in June of that year when he and I were admitted at the same Meeting as members of the Φ.B.K. Society, with the fifty-two years of his life and mine which have since passed away, and felt with double power the melancholy musings of his mind which inspired and pictured out this discourse— The comparison of human life to the annual vegetation and decay of the deciduous leaves of trees is as old as Homer’s Iliad, and the Sermon was an expansive commentary upon the lines of Homer; better adapted to them, than to the verse from the Chapter of Isaiah— The preacher after dinner was a Mr Austin whom I had never heard before. His text was from Matthew 6.10. “Thy kingdom come.” I spent the Evening, with Charles at Governor Everett’s, where we found Mr P. C. Brooks. There came in also while we were there a young Englishman, by the name of Everett— While we were out Miss Harriet Webb and her nephew were here.

Morning absorbed in writing till breakfast—reading only § 55 of Dr Pearson— A portable transit instrument by T. Jones— Between Breakfast and dinner I visited Dr Channing—Mrs S. A. Otis, Mr Saml T. Armstrong Mr Abbott Lawrence and Mrs Dexter. Saw only Dr Channing and Mrs Dexter. None of the rest were at home— I had a conversation again of two hours or more with Dr. Channing upon the subject of the abolition of Slavery.— The Doctor was heretofore an idol of the party now calling themselves whigs, has become very obnoxious to them— They had almost worshiped him as a Saint— They now call him a Jacobin.— He a deeply sensitive to this change in his worldly fame, and exceedingly fearful that the abolition cause will go to ruin, or that the abolitionists will stir up an insurrection of Slaves, and lead to a dissolution of the Union— In his youth he resided sometime in Virginia and is well acquainted with the character of the planters in that State, which he thinks has undergone a great and remarkable change since he lived there; that is, within the last forty years. He was then struck with the great, and unbounded security in which they lived in the midst of their Slaves and surrounded by them, and nightly at their mercy for their lives— They were also then a people careless of property, improvident and thriftless, and generally wasting their estates in expenses beyond their means— He thought them now at least as economical, thrifty and parsimonious as the people of the North. He spoke of the family in which he lived, the heads of which had been at one period while he was there been absent sometime from home, leaving him in charge of the domestic establishment— And there was then one Slave who slept not in the house himself, but came regularly every evening and locked him in for the night and carried away the key.— Much of this security was owing to the fact that among the household Slaves there was almost always one or more profoundly attached to their masters, and if ever any project of insubordination or disorder was formed among the field-Slaves, the House Servants always, disclosed it to their Masters— The Doctor said there were now
now at the South many women, inclined to favour the abolition of Slavery— That in the course of the last Summer, he had travelled in company with a Lady of Baltimore, who told him that she was herself an abolitionist, and that multitudes of Southern women were so at their hearts— But he recurred continually to the fear, that the Southern Slave-holders would dissolve the Union— Said he had heard it had been remarked by Mr Cushing that there was a growing coldness, on the part of the Southern members towards those of the North; and asked me how the Southern members treated me— I said they all treated me as gentlemen, and most of them with kindness and courtesy— That Mr Cushing had been desirous of a very intimate personal intercourse with the Southern members, and perhaps had seen some change in their deportment towards him— I had thought it apparent that they generally held in contempt the Northern members who truckled to them, such as John Randolph had nicknamed dough-faces— But there was so marked a difference between the manners of the South and of the North, that their members could never be very intimate personally together— The Doctor appeared to entertain a great distrust of the political action of the abolitionists; and feared they would ruin their own cause and its friends— He asked me to write to him which I promised to do.— I met at Mrs Dexter’s, her Son Franklin Dexter’s wife— I went with Charles this Evening to the Theatre, and saw the Somnambula, with a very amusing afterpiece, call truth, or a glass too much.— In the Opera the part of Amina was performed by Miss Shirreff—Elvino by Wilson, Count Rodolpho by Seguin— The performance was much better than when I saw it last Spring at Washington. The house was full, but I scarcely knew a Soul present— Mr S. B. Barrell came round to the box where I was, and spoke to me— Home a quarter before 11.—The general election was held this day; but no stranger accustomed to turbulent elections could have suspected it.— The whole city was as quiet, as on a Sabbath day.— It was ascertained that the whole whig ticket here was elected.— But the democratic ticket had an increase of 800 votes since the last year—

When we came out last evening before 11. from the Tremont Theatre, there was a bright Northern light and, it was the anniversary of the day renowned for its morning shower of luminous meteors in 1833. This morning the moon was in close conjunction with the Planet which I have been since the beginning of last month taking for Venus, but which proves to be Jupiter; while that which I have been taking for Mercury, and which so suddenly has disappeared since last Tuesday is Venus.— The stars in such near conjunction the first days of last month were Jupiter and Venus— Mercury was then very near them both, but I saw him only one morning, and then without knowing him. The Almanack gives 3:15 as the time of the Moon’s rising this morning, and as the planet rose within 5 minutes of the same time it is evidently receding from the Sun, while Venus is to become the Evening star on the 20th. of next Month— Jupiter became morning Star on the 21st. of September.— The conjunction of the 3. Planets was about the 3d. of October. Immediately
Immediately after breakfast, I went out to Quincy with Charles, and stayed about two hours there— A man named Sears, brought me a subscription book, for the new whig Magazine and review to be edited by Henry L. Brent, at Washington. He said he had been to Mr. Webster, who advised him to come to me to ascertain whether I had engaged to write for this periodical, as the editor of the prospectus had affirmed; and whether I would subscribe for it— I told him the Editor had written to me, to request me to write for the work; but I had made no engagement so to do, and I would determine whether to subscribe for it or not; after reaching Washington— A Captain Joshua Drew of Duxbury, brought me a Letter from Mr Gershom B. Weston— Captain Drew was Master of a vessel sailing between New-Orleans and Liverpool and on arriving at New-Orleans lately had been required to pay 253 dollars foreign tonnage, because the men of his crew did not answer to the names on his shipping paper— The reason he said was that he had been obliged to ship a new crew at the very moment before he sailed; and had not had time to change the names—but he had two affidavits from Officers of the Custom house at New-Orleans—(not the Collector) that the men of his crew, all excepting two, (were Americans) and a certificate from the Consul at Liverpool, Ogden, that there had been no trouble about these Seamen— Captain Drew told me, what did not appear upon the papers, that these men were free blacks— And that the Secretary of the Treasury had sent back his petition to have the foreign duties refunded, with the answer that the application must be to Congress— I told Captain Drew that if he would have his Petition made out in duplicates, to the two Houses, I would present the one to the House, and move its reference to a Committee; but I thought they would require, besides his papers attesting that they were all but two Americans, proof of the name of each man, and that he was an American— He said he could not procure this proof, because he knew not where the men now were— I said I would nevertheless present his petition, and do what I could to obtain a favourable decision upon it— I received a Letter from my wife, advising me to wait some days longer before proceeding to Washington, as she was about removing to our house in F. Street, which Dr Huntt’s widow has concluded to evacuate— I returned at 1. O’Clock with Charles, to Boston; and at 3. we went and dined with Mr P. C. Brooks at his house in Pearl Street. His Son Peter C. junr. with his wife live with him— His eldest Son Edward, and Governor Edward Everett were there.— I called and spent the early part of the Evening, at Mr Edward Cruft’s— Three daughters and one small boy were there; and his eldest Son, Edward came in while I was there— He returned this morning from a tour to New-York and Albany— The Election storm has not yet subsided— There has been a violent party convulsion throughout the Commonwealth— The whig party is shivering to atoms, by internal dissension upon the fifteen gallon license law— The Democrats, much more harmonious, and more skilled in the art of electioneering, are yet divided by conflicting individual ambitions— The issue of the election yesterday at Boston
Boston is not yet ascertained, and Quincy has been convulsed in Town-meeting yesterday without being able to effect a choice of Representatives to the State Legislature— They adjourned the Meeting to this day, and now chose Dr Duggan, a Democrat—and could not effect the choice of a second. In the 12th. Congressional District, there was no nomination of a candidate in opposition to me— But an opposition was secretly organized throughout the District, utterly unknown in many of the Towns, until the opening of the polls— No preparation had been made for such resistance, and multitudes did not vote, from the mere presumption that as there would be no opposition, it would be useless— To play the game with more effect a highly charged democratic abolitionist was selected for the Candidate, and the whole Van-Buren phalanx in every town of the District voted for him— Instead of an unanimous vote, my majority in the District will be but a few hundreds.
To Quincy with Charles. His Lecture

There was a heavy shower of rain in the Night but the morning was again clear.— The moon rose after four, about 12 degrees distant from Jupiter with whom she was yesterday in conjunction— I wrote industriously till breakfast; immediately after which I had a visit from Mr E G Loring, who invited me to meet him and the other Gentlemen, subscribers for my portrait by Page, at his painting room on Friday morning at 11. O’Clock, which I promised— I wrote to my wife, to inform her, that I shall postpone my departure for Washington, till I hear from her again. I called at Charles’s Office, and then at the Quincy Stage Office where I found Gillet. He had a note from Jonathan French the Schoolmaster at Quincy to say that Charles was expected there, to lecture at the Lyceum— He had directed Kirk to ask French who is the Secretary of the Lyceum to send him such notice, if he was expected— At Mr Page’s chamber I found a Lady sitting to him for her Portrait.— He asked me for another sitting, which I promised for ten O’Clock, Friday Morning— Met Daniel Parkman at the door of N. 22 School Street, and walked with him to Summer Street— There I left cards for Mr Daniel Websters, and Mr John Welles’s houses— Then called at Mr James H. Fosters in Bedford Street— Saw Mrs Foster and her daughter, Mary, whose health has improved— Mrs Foster told me that her Son William was still afflicted, at the insane hospital— I called next at Mr Tarbell’s, and left cards for him and for Mr Fletcher—after dinner, I came with Charles out to Quincy— Went to Mrs T. B. Adams’s to tea. Her Son, passed Midshipman Joseph Harrod is with her, on a leave of absence from the line of Battle Ship Ohio, now at New-York; and bound on a three years cruize under the command of Commodore Hull in the Mediterranean— Elizabeth is also with her mother.— At 7. O’Clock I went with Charles to the Town-Hall, where he delivered a Lecture upon the Revolution of American Independence as affected by the manners and habits of social and domestic life— The Hall was crowded and more than half the auditory were women.— The most perfect silence was observed and the deepest attention paid, throughout the reading, which occupied an hour and a quarter— Mr Peter Whitney, Mr Lunt, and the
the episcopal Minister Mr Wolcott were there— After the Lecture, we came to pass the Night at my house— There was a Northern light almost equal to the light of a full Moon— Charles had already delivered this same Lecture with great credit at the Historical Society in Boston, last Winter—

One of my chief purposes for staying here this day was to finish my seed, nut, stone and acorn sowing, in which from the first of October I have been disappointed by alternate hard frosts and flooding rains— A steady rain the whole of this day disappointed me again and confined me to the house— I only had the seedling Pear trees from the Brown-Bury seed transplanted from the two Pots to the Seminary stands.— I had a long morning visit from E. Price Greenleaf, and Mr Ayer the Carpenter from Boston who came out this morning for some work upon Charles’s house dined with me— Mr Greenleaf, gave me an account of the recent elections here, in which there was no violence—perhaps no absolute fraud—but abundance of trickery.— The election in the morning was only for the member of Congress at a Town meeting, upon the projected road from Braintree through my Penn’s hill lands to the granite quarries.— The meeting was thinly attended, and none but the initiated knew that a vote was to be given other than for me— But as soon as the polls were opened, a ticket for William Morton Jackson of Plymouth came forth, and was announced, and recommended as the abolition ticket.— The vote was 115 for me, and 83 for Mr Jackson— But the great struggle was in the afternoon, for the State, County and Town Offices. The Selectmen had published in the Quincy Patriot of the 3d. instt. a list of the qualified voters of the town 593 in number— There were at the afternoon meeting upwards of 400 present; and the democratic ticket for Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Senators prevailed by a large majority— Then for the representation of the town in the State Legislature, after several trials, Dr. W. B. Duggan the democratic manager was elected; and the adjourned over to the next day. They voted then many times, and finally chose Lemuel Spear, the Fence-viewer, Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s farmer, a democrat, and James Newcomb the Select man a whig— The Democratic competitor Nathaniel White could not be carried— The opposition to the State Government sympathises with the National Administration and their watchword is democracy, the supremacy of the People— I wrote to my wife, and enclosed a Letter to her from SarahGrimké. I found on my unanswered file a Letter of 1. September, from Leonard Bliss junr corresponding Secretary to the Kentucky Historical Society at Louisville, informing me that I had been elected an honorary and corresponding member of that Society—and asking for a copy of my fragment Speech and others. I answered the Letter and made up a packet of ten pamphlets of my composition to be forwarded with it— I also addressed to the Revd. Charles W. Upham, at Salem, sundry extracts from the Journals of the English House of Commons in 1650–51. which I had made
made 18 months since for him and had never sent him. I attempted to look up some of my old manuscript books and papers; but the time slipped away and the day was gone—

To the rain of all yesterday succeeded a thick fog this morning, and a cloudy day with light showers and a clear evening. I made the Diary record of yesterday before breakfast— Mr Ayer breakfasted with me, and at half past 8. Gillet came with the Quincy Stage and took us to Boston— Mrs Patton Hall was also in the Stage, returning from a visit she has been making to Mrs John Greenleaf— I alighted at Charles’s house: immediately after which I went to Mr Page’s painting room, and sat about half an hour; at 11. O’Clock there came in quick succession about 20 gentlemen, the subscribers for whom this portrait had been painted—among whom were Richard Fletcher, Abbott Lawrence, Josiah Quincy jr. Jonathan Phillips, Isaac P. Davis, Joseph T. Buckingham, George Parkman, Ellis Gray Loring, Francis Jackson,Chapman,Shaw, a son of Robert G. Shaw, and some others, with whom I was not personally acquainted— After viewing the Portrait, Mr Loring addressed them, and said that it would now be necessary to determine what disposal to make of it— Mr Phillips was then chosen Chairman of the Meeting, and with five others was appointed a Committee to withdraw and report Resolution to the Meeting for adoption— The went accordingly and soon returned with a Resolution that the Portrait should be presented to the City of Boston, to be suspended in Faneuil Hall. This Resolution was unanimously adopted, and the same Committee were charged with the Office of presenting the picture to the City authorities. They then passed a vote of thanks to Mr Page, for the handsome execution of the work; and a motion was made for a vote of thanks to me, for the favour of sitting to the Painter—upon which I interposed, and said that I felt this would be an inversion of the part suitable to be performed between them and me— That the thanks were due from me to them, and that I offered them with the deepest sensibility to their kindness— That when requested by two of them to sit to the Artist, I had cheerfully complied without knowing or enquiring what was the purpose of the proposal, nor had a conjecture entered my mind upon this subject till I was now made acquainted with it— That I intreated them to believe that I felt it as an honour doubly precious, in the act itself, and in the delicacy of the manner in which it had been performed—and if the return of my thanks to them was not expressed in elegance of language suitable to the occasion, I hoped they would attribute the deficiency of words, to the pressure of an overburdened heart.— Mr Phillips the Chairman made a brief complimentary reply, and the meeting dispersed— I then went with Dr George Parkman to the house of DrBowditch, a son of the late Nathaniel Bowditch, and saw his library consisting chiefly of the Transactions of learned Societies, and works upon
upon Astronomy— The present Doctor Bowditch’s wife, an English Lady, and his Sister, a daughter of the late Doctor were there— The Library was in the parlour— I then returned to Charles’s house, and Dr. Parkman took the Volume of Pearson’s practical Astronomy which he had borrowed for me— Mr P. C. Brooks dined with us at Charles’s—and I went and spent the Evening with Mr Abbott Lawrence. He is perhaps the most leading man of whig politics in Boston; though not at present in any public office.— I had much conversation with him upon the present condition and prospects, both of the national and State politics— Mrs Lawrence occasionally came in; and once with her son, a lad of about 12 years old.— Lawrence is a frank open hearted man, who with a good school but not classical education has made a large fortune, and lives in much Affluence and hospitality— He has been for many years devoted to Mr Webster and the main pillar of his support both pecuniary and political— He now thinks Webster has coalesced with Harrison against Clay upon the Presidential competition, and is himself for Clay— But such is the ascendancy of Webster over his party, that he treats his friends as Goldsmith says Garrick did his—
He cast off his friends, as a huntsman his pack,
For he knew, when he pleas’d, he could whistle them back—

Between 9 and 10 this morning, Mr Brooks called upon me with his carriage, and I went with him to the rural cemetery at Mount Auburn— I think it is five years since I was there before. There are therefore many monuments there now more than there were then— Among the rest that of Spurzheim the phrenological professor— There are now a number of enclosures within durable iron railings of spaces of various dimensions from ten to perhaps 100 feet square— One with the name of Lawrence, wrought in gilt Letters into the railing— The grave of Edward Bangs, sometime Secretary of the Commonwealth was covered over with evergreens, and black, white and red berries growing on small and slender stalks, apparently without roots; none of them elevated more than three or four inches over the sod, and how they have been made to grow there we could not devise. There is very little variety in the monuments yet existing, and not one epitaph or monumental inscription suited to teach the rustic moralist to die— The barrenness of obituary sentiment or reflection is the most striking character of the place— Few instances of any thing more than the name and years of the incumbent; and almost all the inscriptions carved in the stone, without colouring so that it is scarcely possible to read them— A long slender pyramidical shaft, of Marble, Granite or Connecticut Stone with the names engraved on one side of the shaft, and standing on a low pedestal, is the most common form of the grave stone— Upon one of these pyramids on the grave of an Officer in the Navy, there is carved in relief, a silk worm feeding
feeding on a mulberry leaf, lying on the web of his cocoon unfolded like a sheet, and over him a flame, out of which issues a butterfly— This emblem of immortality was almost the only reminiscence of the Soul, that I discovered in the garden— The ground was covered with the dry, and snuff-coloured leaves of Oak, Chesnut and Walnut trees, and the trees themselves intermixed with Pine, fir, hemlock, Cedar, ash, beech, the arbor vitae and various shrubbery, with two or three ponds of stagnant water, cover the alternate hillock and valley of about 100 acres of land.— There is upon it a small comfortable dwelling house, in which the keeper of the enclosure lives; and the appearance of the whole now partakes of the desolation of the Season— On our return to Boston, I left a card at Mrs Lloyd’s, and met in the Street Alexander H. Everett and Solomon Lincoln— Received a Letter from my wife, advising me still to remain some days here— I dined with Charles at Mr Isaac P. Davis’s.— Judge John Davis, with Mrs Isaac P. and her Son Thomas K. formed the whole party— Mr George Bancroft came in after dinner, and we had a long conversation, of which I engrossed too much— Mr Bancroft engaged me to dine with him next Friday, if I should be here— On returning home, we found Governor Everett, making a short evening visit.

I omitted the mention yesterday of a morning visit from Harriet Welsh, and some conversation with her, upon the claim of the granddaughter of Coll. Richard Gridley to a pension, which I ought not to forget at Washington— I omitted also to notice the most affecting incident of my visit to mount Auburn— It was the solitary inscription, of the name of Maria Osborne Sargent, wife of Charles P. Curtis; born in 1804. deceased at the age of 30 in 1835—daughter of Daniel Sargent and Mary Frazier once to me the most beautiful and most beloved of her sex— In the 15th. year of her age she gave me, then 22 the assurance of her affection and the pledge of her faith— A year afterwards she withdrew them, from distrust instilled into her mind, by an anxious cousin.— Twelve years afterwards She married Daniel Sargent, and in 1804 at the age of 30. died of a consumption consequent upon the birth of this only child— This child I never saw— She too closed her career at the early age of 30. and upon meeting unexpectedly here the inscription of her name upon the grave-stone, a mingled emotion of tenderness, of melancholy, and yet of gratitude to Heaven, affected me to tears— I imagined to myself what would have been her fate and mine, had our union been accomplished— That in all probability I should have lost her in the prime of life, and lost perhaps a child like this, cut off like this in the blossom— Dearly!—how dearly did the sacrifice of her cost me, voluntary as it was—for the separation was occasioned by my declining to contract an unqualified engagement, forbidden by my father, and by the advice of her cousin to her, to insist upon a positive engagement or a separation— Four years of exquisite wretchedness, followed this separation, nor
nor was the wound in my bosom healed, till the Atlantic Ocean flowed between us—till all the faculties of my Soul, were absorbed in the politics of a revolutionary period, and the incidents of a wandering and adventurous life, led me to the formation of other and more propitious ties—by which I am yet happily bound. At the first Church Dr Thomas Gray, of Jamaica Plains, Roxbury, supplied the place of Dr N. L. Frothingham, who is yet confined to the house by a catarrhal complaint, following a bilious attack— Dr Grays morning text was from Colossians 3.1.— “Seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God”—and that of the afternoon from Matthew 7.1. [“]Judge not that ye be not judged— 2. For with what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged: and with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you again.”— I spent the Evening at Coll. Josiah Quincy junrs. and met there Mrs Lloyd, Mr William Minot, and Mr Horace Mann— Also Miss Abby Quincy— We had conversation about phrenology and Dr. Combe— Mrs Quincy and Mr Mann are Phrenologists. Mr Minott walked with me home— Evening fall of snow

The sky cleared away this morning at Sunrise, and the day was fine; the Snow melting in the Sun, and freezing in the shade. I called about noon at Charles’s Office, but he was not there. I then visited Doctor N. L. Frothingham, and found him confined to his chamber with a severe cough, and stricture at the breast— While I was there, Governor Edward Everett came in— The walking in the Street was so bad that I could not pay any other morning visit— At half past 3. P.M. Mr Curtis came, and I gave him the duplicate signed by me of the Letter from the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to Petty Vaughan, accepting his offer of a composition for his debt— I assented also to Mr Curtis’s proposition for selling a further portion of the landed Estate at Princeton— In the Evening I went into Hancock Street; and in search of the house of Mr Patton Hall, by mistake found myself in that of Mr Joseph Hall junr, the eldest son of my old friend— His wife and four children were with him— I afterwards found the house of Mr Patton Hall, and spent an hour with him, and his wife, the youngest daughter of my mother’s uncle Isaac Smith. Three sons of Mr Hall, and one daughter by a former wife were present— On my return to my Son’s house, I found Mr Abbott Lawrence, who had been here, an hour or more to visit us— He told us Mrs Lawrence was going to-morrow to New-York; and he is to follow her on Friday or Saturday.— I read this morning Pearson’s §56. Directions for the examination and adjustments of a Transit instrument— But I have no disposable time to read here.

Clear cold morning— Arcturus, the Northern Crown, and Jupiter visible in the East and South East— The Pleiades and Hyades with the Bull’s eye Orion—the large equilateral triangle of Betelgeuse, Procyon and Sirius, and the twins, all descending in the West— Morning visit from Mr John Parker in the 82d. year of his age; one of the wealthiest men in this Country; and one of the most respectable character— His Fortune has been all acquired by his own industry; and his great solicitude now is how to make it secure.— More secure than property can be made. He has gloomy forebodings of the dissolution of the Union, even before his own; and he is much dissatisfied with the proceedings of Mr Biddle, and the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States— He foresees convulsions in the value of property, by the abuses of banking, which I dread little less than he— But I said we must travel on in the journey of life; taking up with such fare, as the chances of the road can supply—and ready to sink at every stage into the repose of eternity; or like Howard on the way side, between Stage and Stage, without dreaming of a home, or abiding place upon Earth.— I finished an answer to two Letters from Origen Bacheler of New-York; soliciting a donation of money to the Peace Society, and the latter accompanied with a printed draught of a Petition and Memorial to Congress which he is circulating for signatures, and which he says will be sent to me for presentation— Before dinner I walked out, and paid visits—leaving cards at Mr Jeremiah Mason’s, and Mr Benjamin Gorham’s— Mr Joseph B. Felt was not at home, but Mrs Felt received me, and the sight of her mother’s picture by Stewart, an excellent likeness awakened tender and pleasing recollections— I met there Elizabeth Foster and Miss Susan Hall— At Mr James H. Foster’s I saw Mrs Foster, Louisa, Mary, and Louisa C. Smith—and at Mr Frothingham’s I met the Revd. W. P. Greenwood, and Buckingham the Editor of the Courier— Mrs Angier of Medford dined with us at Charles’s, and the condition of the Streets deterred me from attempting to make any evening visits— Miss Harriet Welsh was here, with her nephew, Charles, a Son of the late Thomas Welsh— I was looking into the volume of Dr Johnsons poems, for a hymn which Mr Greenwood and Mr Frothingham had shewn me in the Brattle-Street Church hymn book, and of which they asked me if I knew the original— It is a translation from the Latin, but I knew not from whom. I did not find it in the volume of Poems; but I did find the Tragedy of Irene, remembered that I have never read it— I read it now, and found it a totally different thing from what I supposed it—bearing in comparison with Shakespear some analogy to that of warm water with Maraschino de Zara— I fall irresistibly into desultory reading, from the gallery of Actors and Actresses on the Theatre Francais, to Cousin’s Report, the North American Review and the Journals of the Provincial Congress of 1774 5. and. 6.

Bright morning Stars— Sun rose at 7— 3. true time Immediately after breakfast, I went with Charles out to Quincy, and at 1. O’Clock P.M. met Mr Humphrey the Surveyor at the Mount Wollaston farm Deacon William Spear was there; and Mr Benjamin V. French, with another man, Hollis, Ambrose S. Brackett and Lewis Bass— Mr French and Mr Hollis shewed me their Deeds which bound on my upland, but without any admeasurement— I paced the distance of French’s line, and found it 206 paces or by estimate 1030 feet or in round numbers 60 rods— I had with me the plan of my farm, surveyed by Mr Humphrey in October 1830— He now staked out the line, as he judged it to run between the Saltmarsh, and the upland; but the line is so winding, that the marsh in several places surrounds the upland; in which cases, Mr Humphrey considered the insulated upland, as included in the Meadow— Being obliged to return to Boston to dine, we could not stay for the admeasurements, with Hollis, Wild (who was not there) Brackett, and Bass. We left them engaged in the work of staking out the line, between the Saltmarsh, and upland; and returned to Boston— Alpheus Spear was absent—gone to Cohasset— The weather was pinching cold, and the ground at Quincy was covered with glaring snow. We returned within an hour and dined with Governor Everett; Mrs Everett, with Mr Peter C. Brooks; his Sons Edward and Peter C. junr, and Isaac P. Davis with Charles and myself formed the company— I had much conversation with the Governor after dinner, upon the present prospects of the future presidential election. At 8 in the Evening I went to Dr Francis Parkman’s, to the Meeting of the old Wednesday Evening club of which I was a member in 1790—and again in 1801 and in 1807. till I embarked for Russia in August 1809— At Dr. Parkman’s I met as present members of the club, judge John Davis. Messrs. Young and Lothrop, Clergymen of the City, James Savage, Francis C. Gray, William Gardner and Charles P. Curtis, Josiah Quincy junr. Revd.Freeman a young clergyman from this State, settled at Louisville Kentucky, and a Mr Adams an Englishman from Calcutta, much interested about Education, and the abolition of Slavery— There was much pleasant conversation, and time flew till near midnight when I returned to my Son’s house. Judge Davis, Mr Welles, Mr Benjamin Gorham, and Dr Parkman, had been to visit me while I was out of the City— Dr Parkman had also left the Volume of Horsley’s Sermons, of which I was in quest; and an invitation to attend the Club at his house this Evening— Mr Freeman asked me for a copy of my fragment Speech, and Mr Adam, about my Silesian Letters

Cloudy morning. No Stars— No sight of Encke’s comet. Dr. George Parkman called here, and proposed to me to visit the hospital, and other places; but I was about to attend the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, which I did at noon— Mr Thomas L. Winthrop the President, being indisposed was not there— Nor the Vice-President—so that by the nomination of the Secretary Dr T. M. Harris, my old Classmate, and the vote of the members present, there being little or nothing to do, I was placed in the chair— A few donations were received— The Secretary read a report of his own proceedings, and attendance at the chambers of the Society during the year past—an expected report from a Committee was postponed to the next Meeting— A vote of thanks for the donations; a vote that the Secretary’s Report should be put on the Record—and then the Meeting was adjourned— The attendance was thin; but among the members present were Saml. P. Gardner, Nahum Mitchell, J. T. Austin, Mr Young, Professor Greenleaf, Dr Jencks, Mr Felt, and Isaac P. Davis, with whom I afterwards called at Mr Page’s painting room— He was there, returned from his last excursion to New-York— He told me Dr. G. Parkman, had taken the print of the Quincy Stone Temple, which Page had borrowed to introduce into the back-ground of my Portrait— I went with I. P. Davis, and Charles, whom we met in the Street, to the Athenaeum, and found Clevenger there finishing a bust of Mrs Webster— She was there and Mr Webster’s daughter— She said she had given the artist nine sittings— The bust is a very fine one— There were also good busts of judge Davis, and of Isaac P. and an unfinished one of Daniel Webster— We then went into one of the chambers and saw sundry books of handsome Architecture and engravings sent as a present from Italy by the late George Brimmer, who recently died there—and a series of beautiful lithographic engravings of the Pictures in the gallery at Dresden, all which I recognized as old acquaintance— Returned to dine at my Son’s, and passed the Evening there with a visit from P. P. F. Degrand— I made an extract from Bishop Horsley’s Sermons, and read part of Potter’s Translation of the Ion of Euripides.

No Stars visible, I read Pearson §57— To determine the exact place for a meridian mark.— Finished reading Potter’s translation of the Ion of Euripides. Ion is the son of Creusa, by the God Apollo— At his secret birth, Mercury leaves him in charge of the Priestess of Apollo at Delphi, to be brought up in the service of the God— Creusa afterwards marries Xuthus, and having no children, they go to consult the oracle at Delphi, how to obtain the blessing— Ion has grown to manhood, and the Oracle declares him to be the son of Xuthus but not of Creusa— Whereupon she conspires to poison Ion, by two drops of the Gorgons blood mixed in a bowl of wine— This conspiracy is disclosed to Ion, who thereupon resolves to kill Creusa— But the Priestess of
of the temple prevents the Catastrophe, by declaring that Ion is the Son of Creusa, and by producing the wicker basket in which he was delivered to her at his birth— Minerva finally appears, as a messenger from Apollo, and commands them to return to Athens and there to place Ion upon the throne of his ancestor Erectheus, and foretells that he shall give his name to the Ionian People, and be the father of four Sons, each of whom shall be the founder of one of their tribes—and that to Xuthus and Creusa shall be born a Son named—Dorus, who shall be the father of the Dorians— Dr. George Parkman called, and I went with him and visited the Cabinets of the anatomical Society, and of the Society of Natural History the latter of which is over the chamber of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Met Coll. Benjn Pickman in the Street, and called at the State-house—in the rooms occupied by the Revd Joseph M Felt— I saw the 110 folio Volumes in which he has had bound a large assemblage of old Archives, and files of manuscript papers relating to the History of the Colony Province and State— The two Charters of Charles I. and of William and Mary, were there; and many manuscripts of the sometime Governor Hutchinson— I was also shewn into the Library of the General Court, for which annual appropriations have been made for a few years past, and which as yet is not large— I returned and found Mr and Mrs Nathaniel Amory here on a visit— Wrote to my wife advising her to expect me, next Wednesday or Thursday— I alone dined at Mr George Bancroft’s. Mrs Bancroft Revd. Dr. Channing and W. P. Greenwood—Judge John Davis and his brother Isaac P. and Mr Ellis Gray Loring formed the party Dinner at 4. O’Clock; conversation literary, political, biblical, and miscellaneous, at table till 9. O’Clock or later— I went home, and found Charles and Abby were already gone to a party at Mr Benjamin Gorham’s, to which I followed them—about forty persons, men and women— Supper—and we came home soon after eleven—

After Sunrise the weather cleared off cold; and it grew colder the whole day long. I read Pearson §58— [“]On the errors of the transit instrument, in connexion with a Clock or Chronometer.” and turned over the leaves to the end of the Volume, which consists almost entirely of descriptions of observing instruments. Dr Bigelow paid me a morning visit, and I consulted him, as I had done three years before, upon my growing infirmities— He advised me much as before. Nehemiah Holden a Pensioner at 8 dollars a month brought me a Letter from Abm. R. Thompson of Charlestown— He has a petition to H.R.U.S. on file, presented by Edward Everett at his last Session, which I must call up— It is for an increase of his pension, as an invalid, he having had his arm broken while in the service during the revolutionary War— The former Committee reported against his claim for deficiency of
of Evidence— But he can obtain affidavits from one or two of his brothers which he will send me.— His son was here, before and with him— He also enquired of me concerning a petition against Slavery signed by him, and about 20 other revolutionary pensioners, which I presented last Winter, and of which he shewed me a printed copy— Before dinner, I paid visits to Mrs S. A. Otis, to Mr Thomas L. Winthrop, and to Mr Saml. T. Armstrong— Mrs Otis is upwards of 80 years of age, and looks as if she had yet a long life before her— Mr Winthrop is not much younger, but has not the appearance of lasting so long— Mr Armstrong has made a recent excursion into Virginia; and is one of the Senators elect, from this County, in the State Legislature for the ensuing year— He kept me in political conversation till half past 3. before I got back to Charles’s house to dine. Mr Brooks, W. Lee, Governor Everett, Dr Palfrey, Revd Mr Lothrop and Coll. Josiah Quincy junr were the company, at a pleasant dinner— Charles had been to Quincy before dinner, and went in the Evening to a concert— I had met Edmund Quincy in the street, and he had promised to come, and have some conversation with me this Evening. He came, and I conversed with him freely on the political movements of the Anti-Slavery and abolitionist party— They interrogate all the candidates for the General and State Legislatures, what their opinions are upon sundry questions relating to the abolition of Slavery, and if the answers are not exactly conformable to their opinions they vote against the candidate or scatter their votes to defeat his election— Very few of the candidates answer the questions to their satisfaction, and they shew their power by marring the Elections. The result of their interposition has been hitherto mischievous, and I believe injurious to their own cause. I urged this as strongly as I was able; but apparently without making any impression upon his mind.— The moral principle of their interference, to defeat elections when they cannot carry them, appears to me to be vicious; and I think the first result of their movements will be to bring the two parties together against them.— As yet their political action has only tended to break down the barriers between the parties, the natural consequence of which is to strengthen the administration which they abhor—

The morning was so cold that I could not write before breakfast at-all, and absorbed the time in reading. Mr Armstrong had invited me to go and heard his minister at the Old South Church Mr Blagden He called on me this morning, and I went with him— He told me that his thermometer had been this morning at Zero— Mr Blagden’s discourse was upon two texts— Mark 2.17. [“]When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, they that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick.— I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.” and Luke 19.10. “For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost.”— The Sermon was a sequel to one upon the same texts, preached last Sabbath morning, and presented the Calvinistic doctrine of the atonement in a mitigated form, but arguing that an unexceptionable performance of all the duties enjoined by the commandments of the second table is altogether insufficient for Salvation.— Mr Armstong informed me that his pew was that once owned and occupied by the Patriot Samuel Adams.— Immediately opposite to it
to it was the pew of Mr John Parker, who was there, and who took leave of me in coming out from Meeting— Dr Frothingham attempted this morning to preach at his Church, but the Congregation were broken up by discovering that the House was on fire—which was extinguished without giving a public alarm—but there was no other service there this day— In the afternoon we went to the Brattle-Street Church and heard Mr Samuel Lothrop, from Matthew 5.14 Ye are the light of the world.— The argument of the discourse was that Christianity as a religion, was beyond all others adapted to the animal—the social—the intellectual and the moral nature of man— A Sermon very well written and delivered, but not in the tones of deep and earnest sensibility— Miss Harriet Welsh, and Mr Degrand, called this Evening; and I went with Charles and spent an hour at Mr Peter C. Brooks— His son, and Mrs P. C. Brooks junr. were there, and Mr William Brooks his nephew— There was an alarm of fire in the Evening; which soon ceased. We came home between 10 and 11—

Another change in the condition of my domestic Life.— I have been living more than a fortnight in indolent enjoyment at my Son’s house, without being troubled with the distracting cares of a family, without being dunned, and without disturbance of any kind— From this delightful dream, after two postponements of my departure I was this day compelled to awake. Packing my trunk all the morning, and at last obliged to leave it to my Son Charles wife, who did it for me. Morning visits from Mr Fletcher, Mr Jeremiah Mason, Louisa C. Smith, and Dr George Parkman, to take leave— Mr Fletcher said he should proceed to Washington at the close of the week— It was the day of the second trial to elect members for the City of Boston, in the Legislature of the Commonwealth— The polls were to close at 4. O’Clock P.M—for which I could not wait— At the election of the 12th. instt. only 20 were elected and 36 more were to be voted for now— After an early dinner Charles and his two sons John Quincy and Charles Francis, rode with me to the Depot of the Providence and Stonington Railway— There I met Mr Caleb Cushing of Newbury-Port; on his way to Washington like myself to attend the approaching Session of Congress.— I Took leave of my Son, and his two Children, and at 5 minutes past 3. we started in the cars— Weather fine, clear and cold.— With the twilight after the setting Sun we crossed the Providence river, and just before 9 we alighted at Stonington, and immediately embarked in the Steamer Narragansett for New-York— The expedition of this mode of traveling surpasses the imagination of any thing in former days— Of the aspect of the Country between Providence and Stonington I can give no account, having traversed it in the darkness of the Night— They stopp’d at two places on the road to take a fresh supply of water— At the second I left the car for about 5 minutes— When I returned
returned, I found a young woman in the seat that I had left, and on reaching Stonington the Umbrella that I had left by the side of the Seat, had disappeared— There was no time to search for it, and I give it up as lost.— I only desired the Captain of the Steamer on his return to Stonington to inform the conductor of the Cars that I had lost my umbrella in them; and if he should find it, request him to send it to my Son’s house at Boston— Of my fellow passengers about 80 in number I knew only Mr Cushing, though a Pennsylvanian Anti-Mason accosted me, and told me he had been introduced to me, at an Anti-masonic Meeting at Washington inAbout 11. O’Clock I retired to bed—

The Night was fine—clear and cold—with a bright moon ten days old— A brisk breeze, nearly ahead, a smooth Sea, and a boat in scarcely perceptible motion— Yet I slept little or nothing— We reached the wharf at New-York about half an hour before Sun rise, but too late for the 6. O’Clock boat to Amboy. I had my trunk deposited in the Steam-boat Office, and after calling at the Philadelphia House, where they were not ready for breakfast, I went with Mr Cushing to the Astor House; where we breakfasted— Before which I wrote to my Son, to inform him of my arrival thus far.— On taking my seat at table I found myself by the side of Luther C. Peck, a member of the House of Representatives of the United States from the State of New-York— On looking over the bar-keeper’s books, I found that Mr and Mrs Edward Cruft of Boston were at the House, and visited them at their chamber— They are here upon an excursion for the improvement of Mrs Cruft’s health— While I was there, their second Son, William Smith Cruft came in— A young man, in trade here in partnership with a Mr Newbold— He gave me his card with the name of the firm, and his own, and asked me to send him some commercial documents which I promised— At ten O’Clock we took the Steamer to Amboy; and there at 1/2 past 12 the Cars to Bordentown. By some accident we were detained nearly an hour on this road; and it was half past 3 when we entered the Steamer on the Delaware. Half past 5 when we reached the Chesnut Street wharf, and the Clock struck 6. as we were engaging our lodgings at the Marshall House— After taking my chamber N. 57. I went to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s, but he was not at home— Thence to Mr John Sergeants, and he was just going with his three Sons to the Chesnut Street Theatre— I went with him and saw Mrs Centlivre’s Comedy, the Wonder, a Woman keeps a secret—very indifferently performed.— Excepting Wood as Don Felix, all the rest was dull— Mrs H.
