Cramer as Violante has a voice like the boatswain of a Man of War— The play is a Comedie d’intrigue on the old Spanish platform and the Scene is at Lisbon— The scene of quarrel between the two chambermaids is comic; and shews the authors acquaintance with female character and passions in low life— But Lissardo is a failure of the cunning and sprightly Scapin or Figaro stamp, and Gibby suffers himself to be kicked and cuffed rather too much for the honour of auld Scotland— The play was succeeded by sundry songs and dances and the ballet of La fille mal gardée; performed by a company of dancers from Paris, brought out by a Monsieur Hazard, heretofore a successful dancing master at Philadelphia, but now a third rate ballet-dancer on the stage— Among the songs was
was one in the character of an American Sailor, much applauded and encored, but the whole of which that I could hear consisted of numberless repetitions of the words “A Yankee ship, and a yankee crew.” After the Play Mr Sergeant came with me to the door of the Marshall House; where with the Midnight Clock, I found my bed— Messrs Fillmore, Mitchell and Birdsall, of the New-York delegation in Congress, were with Mr Peck, fellow passengers with us from New-York.
From Philadelphia, to Baltimore and F. Street Washington.

At 7 this morning, with Mr Cushing I embarked in the Steamer Robert Morris at the Chesnut Street wharf— At half past 9 we passed Chester and at ten were at Newcastle— Took immediately the Cars for Frenchtown which we reached in 50 minutes— The transition was made from the cars to the Steamer George Washington, and at a quarter past 3. P.M. we were at the wharf at Baltimore— We preferred this mode of conveyance to that by the Railway Cars over the Susquehannah; but there were with us not more than forty passengers— The Railway has taken from them at least two thirds of their customers, and it will be impossible for the Steamboat line to maintain itself much longer— We had ample elbow room— No crowding— Very good fare at breakfast and dinner— No scramble for Seats, or for the best parts of the dishes— A rapid passages—no delays and treatment always courteous and obliging— The Captain of this boat told me that they consumed sixteen Cords of Pine wood on each passage up and down—or eight cords on every trip— As the passage, is usually little more than four hours, the consumption of wood is about 2 cords of wood, to an hour.— We sent our trunks immediately to the Office of the Washington Railway, and were detained there not more than a quarter of an hour. At 4. O’Clock P.M, the Cars started and at half past 6. we were at the railway house, at the foot of the Capitol Hill at Washington— We had parted from our New-York fellow travellers at Philadelphia— They proceeded in the Railway line, and rejoined us at Baltimore. We found also as fellow travellers from Baltimore, Dr Arnold Naudain, heretofore a Senator of the United States from the State of Delaware; and now a Candidate for the Office of Clerk of the House of Representatives vacated by the Death of Walter S. Franklin, and Mr May, a member of the House from the State of Illinois—with a Lady; I suppose his wife— On landing at Washington we went immediately to the Hall of the House of Representatives, and took our Seats.— By a Resolution of the House adopted at the last Session, the Speaker’s chair has been transferred from the North to the South side of the House, and the whole arrangement of the Seats has been inverted and changed— There was a Resolution that each member should be entitled to a seat, corresponding in advantage with that which he would lose by the reversal— But a circular from the Clerk’s Office was sent some weeks since to every member stating that the new arrangement of the Seats was so different from the former that it was impossible to assign them, and that each member must select his own Seat. I took mine as nearly corresponding to that which I have occupied for
for the last five years, or six Sessions of the House— I then returned to the Railway Office for my trunk—took a hack, and about 7. in the evening alighted at my house in F. Street, to which my wife and family had removed, and where blessed be God, I found them all well.

Thanksgiving day, in my native Commonwealth of Massachusetts; and humble and hearty thanks I give to the disposer of all events, for all blessings that I have ever enjoyed, and particularly for those of the yet revolving year— I paid a morning visit to President Martin Van Buren, whom I found alone in his Cabinet the East Chamber of the Presidential House. Half an hours conversation with him chiefly on the disposal of the Smithsonian bequest— I referred to my conversation with him before my departure hence last Summer—to the Letter I received afterwards from the Secretary of State Forsyth; and to my two Letters to him in answer to it— He had not seen my Letters; but had on his table copies of them, and of a Report from Mr Rush; and of a Letter from President Wayland of Brown University at Providence, all which he said had been sent to him this morning from the Department of State, and none of which he had yet read— With regard to the disposal of the fund, he should leave it entirely to Congress to make provision for it— I recurred to some of the remarks in my Letters to Mr Forsyth recommending the Establishment of an Astronomical Observatory.— He said he had found this idea of an Observatory favourably received by all to whom he had mentioned it. He spoke in high commendation of Mr Rush, for his ability in obtaining the money, from the Court of Chancery, and said that he had recommended his appointment— We had some conversation—also upon the disturbances on the Canadian frontier which he seemed to think more troublesome than I had expected.— He said Mr Fox had been greatly, and he thought unnecessarily alarmed; and had been made to believe that there was a projected invasion of Canada from our side of the river of 200000 men— He said further that the greatest excitement on our side now was on the Michigan border, and the greatest danger at Cleveland.— From the President’s I went to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and saw Messrs. Gales and Seaton— I enquired for Boston Newspapers of Tuesday Morning to ascertain the result of the Election for City Representatives in the State Legislature of Monday— But the papers of Tuesday, had not yet arrived. Evening visit from Mr Woodbury, the Secretary of the Treasury— He invited me to dine with him next Saturday, with the President, and some of the foreign Ministers— I accepted the invitation. But the dining of the President with the Heads of Departments and foreign Ministers, is a novelty introduced by Mr Van Buren; and of which I believe there is no example by any of his Predecessors— Mr Woodbury spoke about the disposal of the funds of the Smithsonian bequest; and gratified me much, by the statement, that the whole fund is now invested at an interest of 6 per cent a year—that the principal sum received is about 508000 dollars; and that it will yield upwards of 30000 dollars
dollars a year— He said further that a question had occurred whether the expenses occasioned by the recovery of the money, were to be deducted from the fund itself, or to be paid by the Public; and the Attorney General had just given an opinion that no deduction from the fund should be made— I told Mr Woodbury that I was delighted to hear this. And I urged most earnestly upon him, as I had done this morning upon the President the duty of this Government, to the honour of the Nation and to the Testator, to keep this fund entire and unimpaired, and to devote its annual proceeds to the generous and glorious object to which it was devoted by him. To no purpose of common education—to no School, College, University or Seminary of Learning— But to the increase and diffusion of knowledge among Men. Mr Woodbury appeared to concur in those views; and I have a faint hope that the fund may be so managed as to produce some useful result— Mr Frye was here this morning.

div.p:
I rose this morning an hour earlier than yesterday, and attempted to write before breakfast— But this I must renounce henceforth during the winter’s cold, and as has often happened to me before must abridge my record, in proportion as the material for it grows important. I wrote to Charles— Called at the Washington Bank, and at Tucker the Tailor’s and went to the Hall of the House of Representatives.— At the Clerk’s Office I enquired for the Journals and Documents of the last Session; but they were not ready to be delivered— Burch, the most efficient clerk in the Office was in perplexity what to do between George W. Jones, andDoty—both claiming the Seat in the House as Delegate from the Territory of Wisconsin.— The questions presented by this case resemble, but are not identical with those of the recent contested elections in Mississippi— The Delegates from Territories are admitted to Seats in the House, with the right of debating but not of voting, by a provision in the ordinance for the Government of the Northwestern territory, adapted by acts of Congress, under the general authority to make needful rules and regulations for the territories, to the organization of Congress in two houses— There are two Laws; one of 1817. which provides that the delegates shall be elected for the same term of two years, for which members of the House of Representatives are elected—and the other of 1836. constituting the territory of Wisconsin and authorising the election of a delegate, once in every alternate year— Under this last law Jones was elected, and it being the second year of the 24th. Congress he sat not only in the second Session of that Congress, but in the first and second Sessions of the present 25th. Congress— At the expiration however of the two years another election was held, and Mr Doty was chosen; and now Jones claims the seat for the remaining Session of this Congress, under the first election, and Doty claims it under the last election— Burch directed the list of the members to be made out, with the name of the Delegate from Wisconsin left in Blank; but not with the seat announced vacant— I enquired for the Journals and documents of the last Session, but they are not yet bound. Going to and returning from the Capitol, I met several members of the House just
just arrived; and among them James K. Polk, the Speaker.— Evening visits from Dr Thomas and from Mr Albion K. Paris theComptroller, and now my next door neighbour.

Day. The first ten days of this month were passed at Quincy much like those of the preceding month; excepting that my family had departed— Then spent upwards of a fortnight with my Son, and his family at Boston; not in idleness, but with too much waste of time— Then in three days I came to Washington, and rejoined my family on the same day of the month, preceding that on which they had left me— I close the present Month with a renewed residence in an old house— My former residence here was in the last rising portion of my life— It is now that in which I may close my career— That it may be one in which the remnant of my days may be devoted to the glory of God; to Peace on Earth, and to the best welfare of my Country, I humbly and devoutly pray.
